intro: Raphanus taquetii, commonly known as the Taquet's radish, is a rare and unique member of the Brassicaceae family. It is native to the arid regions of North Africa, particularly Morocco, where it thrives in rocky and semi-desert environments. The plant features a compact, rosette-like growth pattern with thick, fleshy leaves that store water, an adaptation to its harsh habitat. Its flowers are small and yellow, arranged in racemes, and it produces round, pale brown pods containing several seeds. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Raphanus taquetii is considered a vulnerable species.
